body.p: Mucinous tumors that arise in the retroperitoneum are very rare neoplasms. Like their more common ovarian counterparts, they have traditionally been subclassified as benign, borderline, or malignant, with the malignant form predominating. Less than 30 cases of benign mucinous tumors of the retroperitoneum are on record.

We present the case of a 24-year-old woman who consulted because of pain on the flank, and she was found to have a cystic mass in the retroperitoneum. Grossly, the cyst was 8 cm in greatest diameter. It had a smooth inner surface and was filled with a dense proteinaceous fluid. There were no papillary structures. The cyst was surrounded by a thick fibrous wall lined by a mucinous epithelium that ranged from flat to columnar. The case was interpreted as mucinous cystadenoma of the retroperitoneum (see Figures 1-3).

caption.p: Computerized tomography showing a large mass at the right side of the retroperitoneum. The content of the mass was dense and homogeneous
Gross examination: the mass was cystic with whitish thick walls characterized by a smooth surface with absence of vegetations. On opening the fluid filling the cyst had a proteinaceus appearance

Histopathology of the cyst revealed a dense fibrous wall (A, B) and an epithelial lining alternating areas of flat epithelium (black arrow) and areas of columnar epithelium of mucinous type (red arrow) (C, D)

body.p: As in the retroperitoneum no epithelial cells should be homed, and the histogenesis of mucinous cystic lesions (like all other epithelial cysts of the retroperitoneum) is still debated. The main histogenetic theories that have been advanced to explain this odd occurrence include the following:

list-item.p: Ectopic ovarian tissue/retroperitoneal teratoma: Derived from a migration error of the pluripotential cells and germinal cells during the embryonic period that leads to the development of mature ovarian tissue outside the ovary rather than a germ cell tumor. This hypothesis is disputed because ovarian stroma or other teratomatous tissues are only rarely found associated with the mucinous cystic tumors, even acknowledging the fact that their immunohistochemical profile is very similar (CK20+/−, CK7+). Also, the occurrence of this process in male patients would be hard to explain through this hypothesis.1-4
Celomatic metaplasia: Invagination of the peritoneal lining during embryogenesis with subsequent metaplasia.1-5

Urogenital remnants: Noninvolution of segments of these embryonic structures that undergo cystic changes with mucinous metaplasia of the epithelium. This seems to be the most accepted hypothesis among the various authors, with one study (Roma and Malpica4) having described a case of a cyst with mixed epithelial, mesotelial, and mucinous lining.2,3

Enterogenic duplication: A duplication of the gastrointestinal tract during embryogenesis is the less valid alternative among the histogenetic hypothesis because of the CK7 positivity of the lining epithelium and the ultrastructural features of the neoplastic cells, which fit better those of ovarian mucinous tumors.2,3,5

body.p: From a therapeutic standpoint, surgical resection is mandatory due to the difficulty in achieving a preoperative diagnosis and the potential risk of the development of a malignant tumor.1 Laparotomy and laparoscopy can be performed with both diagnostic and therapeutic aims.2 Some authors have suggested to treat retroperitoneal mucinous tumors in a manner similar to that of ovarian tumors of equivalent stage and grade.3 The prognosis for the benign and borderline tumors is favorable, as long as they have not undergone malignant transformation.3 The most spectacular example of the latter occurrence is the case of a cystic carcinosarcoma developing 40 years after the resection of a benign mucinous cyst in the same region.6
